titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Morning attending the Circuit Court, and at the Insurance Office— Afternoon reading Taylor’s notes on the Oration of Demosthenes for the Crown— First fire in my study. Dr: and Mrs: Welsh—Harriet, and Miss Storer pass’d the Evening here— Mrs: Adams very unwell, and confined the Evening to her chamber— Our son John also unwell— George’s French lesson lost two days successively.
2. At my Office this Morning, and in the Circuit Court— Afternoon at home— Evening with the club at Mr: Buckminster’s— Mr: Bradford of Wiscasset was there.— Resumed George’s lessons.

3. There was this morning a total eclipse of the moon; but as it began about two O’Clock in the morning, I saw only its termination; for which purpose I rose, between 4 and 5. O’Clock this morning— I spent the day principally pursuing my own studies and those of my son George— Attended a Meeting of the Middlesex Canal Company, at 11. this morning; and was chosen one of the Directors for the ensuing year, in the room of Mr: John Joy, who was on the list, and declined accepting— Read this Evening a Book of Thalaba— Mrs: Adams continues confined to her chamber.

bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 4. About noon I walk’d to Cambridge; dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— At 2. attended the Declamation; which continued untill within 5 minutes of 3— After an interval of less than 10 minutes, I commenced my lecture— Read the 4th: Returned immediately afterwards to Boston— Found Dr: Welsh at my house— Heard of a fray yesterday between Selfridge and B. Austin— Read Thalaba Book 4. this Evening.— Mr: Tyng lost his wife Tuesday Morning.

5. My brother with his wife and eldest daughter were in town this day, and called at my house, as they were on their return home— At my Office this Morning; and employed the whole afternoon and part of the Evening, with my son George— He improves in his french learning.— Read Thalaba late in the Evening.

6. Heard Mr: Emerson this Morning; and Mr: Buckminster in the afternoon. His Sermon was upon the character of the apostle John, and the relation of friendship between Jesus and his Apostles— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 149. 150. and taught George the first, of Rousseau’s Odes Sacrées.— Charles was ill this Evening.— Mr: and Mrs: Jos: Hall paid us this day a visit.— Continued the reading of Thalaba—and found in a Note an account and explanation of the word Corpusanse, which I had never heard used but once; and that by a common sailor, at sea, on the 23d: of September 1794— I noticed it in my journal of that day— But taking it merely from the Sailor’s lips I wrote it as it was sounded by him (Coppresant.)

7. This was the day for the Election of Representatives to the next Congress— Mr: Quincy was re-elected by a large majority for this District.— I spent the day as usual; but was more of the morning at my Office— Called at the Insurance Office— Mr: B. Joy again spoke to me on the subject of my going to Washington— Read Thalaba in the Evening.

8. My reading in the Greek Testament slackens my progress in Demosthenes— I took up this morning one of Lucian’s dialogues, and found I could understand a little of it, without recurring to the Latin Translation— It is almost the first symptom I have discovered of making any progress in the Language— I continued on Demosthenes after dinner— Finished reading with George the second volume of Berquin’s Ami des Enfans.

9. My Father came this morning into Town, and I went with him to Cambridge, where we attended a meeting of the Academy— The attendance was more numerous than usual, and there were several communications made— We previously called upon Judge Dana; who made some enquiries respecting certain public papers during the American revolution, from which I suspect him to be writing Memoirs of that period— After the Academy Meeting, we returned to Boston, my father dined, and after dinner went to Quincy.— I was engaged with Mrs: Adams and Catherine to dine at Mr: Mason’s— Mrs: Adams however did not go— There was a Company of twenty-five persons, and the dinner was a splendid one.— Admiral Coffin was there— We came home early in the Evening, and found Mr: Loud, at my house; where he pass’d an hour— I did not attend the Club.

10. Morning at my Office— Afternoon and part of the Evening engaged with George— But there is a dispersion of Spirits after a day of dissipation, which renders assiduous application impracticable— Began reading with him the third volume of Berquin’s Ami des Enfans.— Finished this Evening the reading of Thalaba, and began with Madoc. I also continue my studies upon Demosthenes— The Legislature of the Commonwealth met this day, for the choice of Electors of President and Vice-President.

div.p: 11. Walked to Cambridge, and attended the declamation at 2.— The Speakers were a full hour in the performance, and in less than five minutes I returned to the Chapel and read my fifth lecture— Immediately after which I returned to Boston— Catherine went to a Ball at Mr: Mason’s— Mr: Everett and Mr: De Grand spent the Evening, and supped with us.

12. My brother came into town this morning, and I went out with him after dinner to Quincy; taking my son John with us. I walk’d three miles of the way, untill overtaken by my brother on his return— The President’s Message was this day received, from Washington.

13. Heard Mr: Coleman of Hingham, morning and afternoon— The former was on the character of Zacchaeus. The day was rainy, and of course confined me principally to the house— Of its leisure time I employed a due portion on the Greek of the New Testament, and of Plutarch— Evening, in conversation with my father.

14. Returned to Boston with John in the Quincy Stage. Forenoon at my Office— Letters from Mr: S. A. Otis, and Mr: Giles, with copies of the Message, and the Message itself, under cover from Mr: Quincy and Mr: Cook— In the afternoon, and Evening I heard George read French, and read three chapters of Madoc which we find very dull. The majority of the State Legislature this day chose Electors of President and Vice President.

15. Heavy Storm of Rain all the former part of the day; renewed in the Evening, after a clear interval of two or three hours in the afternoon, during which I went to the Office— The rest of the day I pass’d in my usual studies— Taking up the Port-Royal Greek Grammar and Lucian’s Dialogues, with my other reading— Madoc in the Evening.

16. Forenoon at my Office— Afternoon walking with my children in the Mall— John continues in very feeble health— Attended the Club this Evening at Judge Davis— The meeting was not very full— Wrote something; but it seems to take a week to write a letter—

17. Mrs: Charles Adams and Louisa Smith came in from Quincy this morning— They dined with us, and returned immediately after dinner— Walked with Catherine, and the children in the Mall— Mr: De Grand pass’d the Evening with us. I wrote to Mr: Giles and received a letter from Mr: Cook— Read a little with George, but our visitors abridged much the instruction of this day.

div.p: 18. Dined early and walked to Cambridge just in Season to attend the Declamation, which was not so well performed, as has been usual of late.— At 3. I read my 6th: lecture.— There were several gentlemen who attended— Among them was Mr: Buckminster who after we had pass’d an hour at Mr: Thacher’s chamber walk’d with me into Boston— Catherine pass’d the Evening at Mr: Foster’s— George was much fatigued and read little— I made it a short Evening.

19. At my Office, I wrote part of a letter to Mr: Bacon, but did not finish it. At the insurance Office, Mr: Joy made me a new proposition to go this winter on to Washington; but not such as I think I can accept— The afternoon and Evening employed in teaching George, and reading Demosthenes.— I had some question with Mr: W. Smith and Dr: Joy relative to a pew at Mr: Emerson’s church; but made no final arrangement.

20. I attended this morning at Mr: Buckminster’s, and heard Mr: Nichols, the tutor at College— Mr: Ripley dined with us. In the afternoon I heard Mr: Freeman at the chapel Church, against the doctrine of original sin.— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 151. and 152. taught George the first of Rousseau’s Odes Sacrées—heard him read in Berquin, and read myself a dialogue of Lucian in Greek— We have by common consent drop’d the reading of Madoc, from its excessive dulness.

21. I saw Mr: G. Blake, and Mr: Joy, on the subject of the proposal to go to Washington, and gave my final answer to Mr: Joy, which is not to accede to the terms proposed— I had another application to me upon business, respecting a patent right— On which I saw judge Davis— Afternoon and Evening at home— Read four or five chapters more in Madoc.

22. The Supreme Court of the Commonwealth this day commenced its Session— I wrote to Mr: Bacon. The rest of the day was employed as usual. Our second boy, John continues in a state of health which gives me great anxiety.

23. I attended this morning some time at the Supreme Court, where Chief Justice Parsons is sitting to try Jury Causes. Had some conversation with Mr: Hall at my Office— I called at Mr: Morrill’s respecting the pew in the Church; and at the Assessor’s Office, for a certificate respecting the tax on my house in Hancock Street— Afternoon walk; and in the Evening attended the club at Judge Dawes’s— On returning home I found Mr: Everett here; but he soon left us— Coll: Welles, asked me at the Insurance-Office this day whether I was going this Winter to Washington.

24. My brother and his wife came in from Quincy this morning, and called on us for a few minutes— I was a couple of hours at my Office— Mr: De Grand called, upon some business— I walked to Cambridge, and heard Mr: Peck deliver his introductory lecture; with which I was well satisfied— I returned home and dined late, alone— Gave George a lesson of French; but being much fatigued read nothing in the Evening—

div.p: 25. Attended at my Office, and wrote an opinion for Mr: De Grand— Mr: Dyer called upon me, with the plan for making a Market in our neighbourhood— I walk’d to Cambridge— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Attended the Declamation at two O’Clock— Read my lecture 7. at three; and afterwards walk’d into Boston with Dr: Welsh— I found our son John very unwell, on account of which we all sent an excuse to Mr: Sumner’s, where we had been invited to a Ball— Gave George his french lesson

26. The young Gentlemen who are students in my Office, Mr: Everett, Mr: Gallison, and Mr: Loud, dined with me this day. Mr: White was obliged to go out of Town— Mr: King and Mr: Kinloch also, two students from College dined with us— As did Mr: Shaw— I received letters from Mr: Otis at Washington, with the settlement of my Account relative to the Congress Library.— Received also a few lines from Dr: Eustis, who had called two or three times at my office to see me. I was so much engaged at home that I could not answer him or see him this day.

27. Took possession of the pew N. 110. in Mr: Emerson’s Meeting-house— Heard a Mr: Abbot there. A Young man, who writes uncommonly well— My brother came in from Quincy, with his wife and children, who are going to Haverhill— He returned home this Evening, and took out with him our two elder boys George and John, who are to stay at my father’s untill Thursday; when we are all to go out, to keep Thanksgiving there. I called at Dr: Welsh’s; and afterwards on Dr: Eustis, with whom I had much conversation, on the present State of public Affairs— He mentioned to me a project, which I am to take into consideration, and to see him again to-morrow— I had seen and conversed with Mr: J. Gardner at noon— I am in a situation still of great difficulty, and need that light and assistance, which this world cannot give. I pray for it from above.

28. I saw Dr: Eustis again this morning, for an hour or more at my Office, and had some further conversation with him. He shewed me a paper containing the outlines of his project, and left it with me. Mr: De Grand also called on me, upon business— Afternoon and Evening I employed in writing.

29. Saw Dr: Eustis again; and stated to him most of my objections against taking an active part in the measures which he proposes.— I was some time this Morning in the Court House, where the Chief-Justice of the State is sitting for Jury-Trials. In the Evening, I walked two or three hours with Mr: J. Gardner, and nearly came to a determination to remain politically inactive at present—from a conviction that by now taking a part, I could do little or no useful service to the public.

30. Called at Dr: Eustis’s, and read him the papers, which I had prepared; which as I had expected did partly, but not altogether satisfy him— My brother came to town in the Stage and is going to Haverhill to-morrow— I was employed part of the day in passing Bank-Bills, the credit of which is staggering— I finally pass’d them all to persons who were willing to take them, at the hazard of their failure.— Evening, at Club, at Dr: Dexter’s— Thinly attended.

Day. As the last Month.— But the study of Demosthenes, is almost entirely suspended— The Days are so short, and I am so disqualified from study, without day-light, that I grow lazy in the Morning; and waste more of my time than heretofore— Symptoms of business have at length appeared— And Politics threaten me again—
